info.name: NSO Sample API Requests
info.description:
This only covers a sub-set of the RESTCONF Northbound API, since auto-generated swagger from the application is 200,000 lines of documentation.

Created using https://github.com/NSO-developer/nso-vagrant as a localhost NSO testing environment.

item.name: NSO Device Manager
Step 0. Create a Device in the CDB

body.raw:
<!--
Sample CLI to do the same thing
devices device ios0 authgroup default port 10022 device-type cli ned-id cisco-ios-cli-6.42
state admin-state unlocked
-->


<device>
 <name>ios0</name>
 <address>127.0.0.1</address>
 <port>10022</port>
 <authgroup>default</authgroup>
 <device-type>
   <cli>
     <ned-id xmlns:cisco-ios-cli-6.42="http://tail-f.com/ns/ned-id/cisco-ios-cli-6.42">cisco-ios-cli-6.42:cisco-ios-cli-6.42</ned-id>
   </cli>
 </device-type>
 <state>
   <admin-state>unlocked</admin-state>
 </state>
</device>

request.description: Update the Payload with correct info. Sample XML can be used from Get on existing device or using commit dry run on CLI. Device names, NED-ID, Address and Ports will likely be different depending on your environment.

item.name: Delete a device from CDB Device List
View Device Config
All Devices in Device List: Show Running-config Devices Device

request.description: Note: This can be a very large payload, since it is sending the parsed running config of every single device in the device list, and the NSO application configuration.

item.name: Single Device Config - Show devices device DEVICENAME
Single Device HW / SW Platform Info

item.description: If device config is very nested, you can use the depth=X parameter to see additional hidden layers of nesting.

item.name: Device Config Management
Remove SNMP Community String from Device

item.description: Any element of device configuration modeled in NSO can be configured over the API. The ones given here are just samples. NSO will translate it to the correct commands and can rollback if needed.

item.name: Commit Dry-Run and Rollbacks

request.description: This is using an example for an IOS interface, with the configuration in the payload, but could be any config. The key thing is having the query params ?dry-run=native so NSO knows to not commit it and to respond back with the dry-run data in CLI format.

item.name: Dry Run Rollback: Getting back to current state if commit success

request.description:
This API example uses the following params:
?dry-run-reverse=native&dry-run=native
which tells NSO not to make a commit, by doing a dry-run, and give the response in the payload return with native CLI syntax. 
It will calculate behind the scenes based on the payload sent to NSO what it would take to roll that particular payload back, if the commit was succesful. Basically like a dry-run rollback.

item.name: Commit-Dry Run Remove IP address from interface

item.description: Commit dry-run is NSO not making any change to the device, but telling you what the proposed change will be based on what is already existing on the device, calculating the difference. Rollbacks are when NSO calculates the minimum number of commands to return it to the previous state of configuration before the NSO commit transaction.

item.name: 1. Create a DNS Server Configuration Template

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
sample CLI to do the same:
devices template Standard_DNS_Servers
ned-id cisco-ios-cli-6.42
confi
ip name-server name-server-list 8.8.8.8
exit
exit
exit
ned-id cisco-nx-cli-5.13 config
ip name-server servers 8.8.8.8

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

body.raw:
<!--
cli for same config
conf
devices device ios0 apply-template template-name Standard_DNS_Servers
-->

<input>
	<template-name>Standard_DNS_Servers</template-name>
</input>

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description: This compliance report uses the device config template Standard_DNS_Servers to see if the device has a DNS server of 8.8.8.8, only for IOS devices. If non-IOS devices are applied, they are ignored.

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.
This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
Groups are useful for organizing your devices in a way
that makes sense to you.

Devices can be a member of more than one group,
and device groups can be nested.

CLI Equivalent

devices device-group campus-devices device-name [ ios0 nx0 ]
top
devices device-group backbone-devices device-name [ iosxr0 asa0 ]
top
devices device-group parent-group-all-devices device-group [ campus-devices backbone-devices ]
commit dry-run
commit dry-run outformat xml
top

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

item.name: List Device Single Device Group Details

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

item.name: Simple Sample SNMP Server Service
Create Service Instance for Single Device

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

body.raw:
<!--

CLI Equivalent

admin@ncs(config)# simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance device ios0 dummy 10.0.0.0
admin@ncs(config-simple-sample-snmp-server-service-first_service_instance)# commit dry-run outformat native
native {
    device {
        name ios0
        data snmp-server host 10.0.0.0 traps NSO-COMM-STRING
    }
}
-->
             <simple-sample-snmp-server-service xmlns="http://com/example/simplesamplesnmpserverservice">
               <name>first_service_instance</name>
               <device>ios0</device>
               <dummy>10.0.0.0</dummy>
             </simple-sample-snmp-server-service>

request.description:
Creates a service and applies the corresponding template. In this case the service uses an IP address leaf input to build snmp-server config and apply to the device. 
CLI to do the same:
admin@ncs(config)# simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance device ios0 dummy 10.0.0.0

item.name: Get List of Service Instances for a Service

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
Note: this will only have data if service instances already exist.
Shows all service instances. In this case we have just one. 
CLI version:
admin@ncs# show running-config simple-sample-snmp-server-service
simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance
 device [ ios0 ]
 dummy  10.0.0.0

item.name: Get Service Info For Single Service Instance

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
Note: this will only have data if service instances already exist.
CLI version to do the same:
admin@ncs# show running-config simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
This will remove any configuration template based on the inputs stored in the service. 
CLI way of doing the same thing:
no simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

body.raw:
<!--

CLI Equivalent

admin@ncs(config)# simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance device ios0 dummy 10.0.0.0
admin@ncs(config-simple-sample-snmp-server-service-first_service_instance)# commit dry-run outformat native
native {
    device {
        name ios0
        data snmp-server host 10.0.0.1 traps NSO-COMM-STRING
    }
}
-->
             <simple-sample-snmp-server-service xmlns="http://com/example/simplesamplesnmpserverservice">
               <name>first_service_instance</name>
               <device>ios0</device>
               <dummy>10.0.0.1</dummy>
             </simple-sample-snmp-server-service>

request.description: This example changes the dummy IP input from 10.0.0.0 to 10.0.0.1, so the new server will be deployed to ios0

item.description:
NSO allows you to create any service, with any inputs, to enforce any config, for any devices. 

Here is a simple service for use on IOS devices, where the default yang input of an IP address input called "dummy" is used, and then a simple SNMP config is using that input to render and apply config.
note the key for show interface with 0/0 replace / with 0%2F0

item.name: NSO Root of the App Hierarchy Level Queries
item.description: Note: Root level queries have different headers than other queries. Return All Application and Device Config.
